Text:
Step 1: Think about how to explain 'human aging' to someone reading at the Early Elementary level.
Step 2: Select appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Step 3: Write a paragraph of 150 words that follows your plan. Check it with a colleague or a native speaker if possible.

"Human aging is like when a plant grows. When a seed is planted, it starts small and grows bigger over time. It needs water, sun, and food to grow. In the same way, people start as babies and grow bigger too. As we get older, our bodies change. Our hair might turn gray, our skin might wrinkle, and we might not be as fast or strong as we used to be. This is because our cells, which are like tiny parts that make up our body, start to wear out and don't work as well as they used to. This is called aging. It's a natural process that happens to everyone as they get older."

Step 2: Select appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Step 3: Write a paragraph of 150 words that follows your plan. Use transition words to combine your ideas.

Human aging is like a person growing older, like you when you turn from 5 to 6 years old. But, it's much slower. You can't see it happening every day. Aging is when your body changes over time. Your skin gets wrinkles, your hair turns gray or white, and you might need glasses to see things clearly. Your bones and muscles also get weaker. You might not be able to run as fast as before. This happens to everyone, but it happens at different speeds. Some people might seem old when they are only 50, while others might still feel young when they are 80. But, no matter what, everyone gets older with time. It's a part of life.

Aging is when people grow old, just like how a seed grows into a big tree. It happens to everyone, slowly over time. It starts when we're born, and we keep growing and changing. Our bodies change shape, and we get taller. Then, when we're done growing, we start to get older. Our hair might turn gray, like when something turns old and loses its color. We might not be able to run as fast as we used to, or see as clearly. Our bodies and minds might not work as quickly as before. But, aging also brings good things. We gain wisdom and life experiences. We learn and understand more things. It's all part of life's journey.

Text:
Step 1: Think about how to explain 'human aging' to someone reading at the Early Elementary level.
Step 2: Select appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Step 3: Write a paragraph of 150 words that follows your plan. Check the paragraph for accuracy and clarity.

Human aging is like a plant growing. When a baby is born, they are small and need help. As time passes, they get bigger and learn many things. Their body changes too. They grow taller, their teeth change, and they can do more things by themselves. This is all part of aging.

As people grow older, their bodies work a little differently. They might not see or hear as well. Their skin might get wrinkles. They might need help with some tasks. This is also a part of aging. It happens to everyone as they get older.

Even though aging happens to everyone, it doesn't mean that older people can't do many things. They can still learn new things, have fun, and help others. They have lots of life experiences to share. Aging is a natural part of life.

Text:
Step 1: Think about how to explain 'human aging' to someone reading at the Early Elementary level.
Step 2: Select appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Step 3: Write a paragraph of 150 words that follows your plan. Include a title and attribution.

Title: What is Human Aging?

Human aging is like a plant growing older. Just like a tiny seed grows into a big, strong tree over time, our bodies change as we get older. When we are babies, we are small and need help for everything. As we grow up, we get bigger and stronger. Our teeth come in, and we start to walk and talk. When we become adults, we can take care of ourselves and others. But as we keep living, our bodies start to slow down. Our skin might get wrinkles, our hair might turn gray, and we might not be as fast or strong as we used to be. This is all a normal part of growing older, called aging. It happens to everyone, and it's just another part of life.
